content: Recommending Opera VPN as a viable option for privacy *may* be okay for most folks, but not those who actually *need* it. As you mention, but only in passing, “On 10 February 2016, a group of Chinese investors offered $1.2 billion to buy the company: “Opera’s business model is as an ad network. “Opera is an ad network and collects your usage data for those purposes.” Hardly a VPN, then, see: https://thatoneprivacysite.net/2016/05/27/operas-baked-in-vpn-is-not-a-good-solution-for-your-privacy/ Worse, if you’re an activist or, worst, a penniless journalist like me trying to protect their sources, more from the same guy; “Opera purchased SurfEasy VPN just over a year ago: “SurfEasy is a VPN company located in Canada (a five eyes country) “They keep bandwidth and usage logs. These are temporary, but they’re still logs.” I’m stealing his stuff wholesale here so it’s well worth mentioning that his site is dedicated to detailed comparisons of VPN providers, including reviews and comparison charts. The detail can be confusing so the main thing to remember is in the first chart column under “Good Privacy”. One (second to) last thing to remember: “Remember, if you aren’t paying for it, YOU are the product. Opera isn’t doing this out of the kindness of their heart, they are in it for your data as that’s how they operate. There are many VPN companies that do not log their users data. They might ask a fee, but that’s what’s required for the best possible privacy in this arena. Also: “Here’s a good article with more info by HelpNet Security.”
